page.title: Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 44: Line 44:
===Mubaraks===
===Mubaraks===
  +
{{see|Hosni Mubarak|Suzanne Mubarak|Gamal Mubarak|Alaa Mubarak}}
On February 28, 2011, Egyptian Prosecutor General Abdel Magid Mahmud put a freeze on the assets of ousted president Hosni Mubarak and his family and imposed a travel ban on them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/mubarak-banned-from-leaving-egypt-assets-frozen-88439 |title=Mubarak banned from leaving Egypt, assets frozen |publisher=Ndtv.com |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Subsequently the Egyptian government asked the U.S. and the European Union to freeze the assets of the Mubaraks, while an investigation is carried out into widespread allegations of profiteering by Mubarak, his wife Suzanne, and their sons Alaa and Gamal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2011/February/21%20n/Egyptian%20Government%20Wants%20Mubarak%20Family's%20Foreign%20Assets%20Frozen.htm |title=Egyptian Government Wants Mubarak Family's Foreign Assets Frozen |publisher=Aljazeerah.info |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> On March 6, Mohamad Hamouda, Mubarak's lawyer during his presidency, stated that he agreed to represent Mubarak on certain conditions, including that the Mubarak family inform him of their exact assets. Hamouda also stated that Mubarak will take legal action against British newspaper ''The Guardian'' and American newspaper ''The New York Times'' for defamation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21530&catid=150&Itemid=69 |title=Mohamed Hamouda: Mubarak does not have anything |publisher=Alwafd.org |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> On the following day Hamouda withdrew from legal representation for the Mubaraks, citing his "discomfort" with the case. Hamouda stated that achieving justice in this case will be difficult, and explained that he was given only three days to review evidentiary documents and two days into this period he had not yet received these documents from the prosecutor. Hamouda stated that another lawyer, Mourtada Mansour, would represent the Mubaraks. Cairo criminal court was scheduled to start proceedings in this case on March 8, 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbashayer.com/news-130937.html |title=Ø¬Ø±ÙØ¯Ø© Ø§ÙØ¨Ø´Ø§ÙØ± | Ø­ÙÙØ¯Ø© ÙØ¹ØªØ°Ø± Ø¹Ù ÙØ¶ÙØ© ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙÙØ±ØªØ¶Ù ÙÙØ¨Ù | |publisher=Elbashayer.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> however, on that day neither Mubarak nor his council appeared in court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/march/8/mobarak_money.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª ØªØ¤ÙØ¯ ÙØ±Ø§Ø± Ø§ÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø¨ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ù Ø¨Ø§ÙØªØ­ÙØ¸ Ø¹ÙÙ Ø£ÙÙØ§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙØ£Ø³Ø±ØªÙ |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-08 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The court reaffirmed the travel ban on the Mubarak family and upheld the decision by the prosecutor to freeze the Mubaraks' accounts, citing that there is sufficient evidence to suspect Mubarak and his family of profiteering and misappropriation of public funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/465/2011/03/08/27/66267.aspx |title=Lawyers did not attend it ... Cairo Criminal Endorses the decision of the Attorney General to hold the funds Mubarak and his family |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The Mubaraks were contesting the travel ban in appeals court, while a criminal court was to convene to consider the financial charges.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hamad Al-Chalabi and Fatima Abu Shanab |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289932&IssueID=2069 |title="The police" supports the prevention of Mubarak and his family from their money and "Court of appeal" postpone the disclosure of confidential accounts for today's meeting |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
On February 28, 2011, Egyptian Prosecutor General Abdel Magid Mahmud put a freeze on the assets of ousted president Hosni Mubarak and his family and imposed a travel ban on them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/mubarak-banned-from-leaving-egypt-assets-frozen-88439 |title=Mubarak banned from leaving Egypt, assets frozen |publisher=Ndtv.com |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Subsequently the Egyptian government asked the U.S. and the European Union to freeze the assets of the Mubaraks, while an investigation is carried out into widespread allegations of profiteering by Mubarak, his wife Suzanne, and their sons Alaa and Gamal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2011/February/21%20n/Egyptian%20Government%20Wants%20Mubarak%20Family's%20Foreign%20Assets%20Frozen.htm |title=Egyptian Government Wants Mubarak Family's Foreign Assets Frozen |publisher=Aljazeerah.info |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> On March 6, Mohamad Hamouda, Mubarak's lawyer during his presidency, stated that he agreed to represent Mubarak on certain conditions, including that the Mubarak family inform him of their exact assets. Hamouda also stated that Mubarak will take legal action against British newspaper ''The Guardian'' and American newspaper ''The New York Times'' for defamation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21530&catid=150&Itemid=69 |title=Mohamed Hamouda: Mubarak does not have anything |publisher=Alwafd.org |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> On the following day Hamouda withdrew from legal representation for the Mubaraks, citing his "discomfort" with the case. Hamouda stated that achieving justice in this case will be difficult, and explained that he was given only three days to review evidentiary documents and two days into this period he had not yet received these documents from the prosecutor. Hamouda stated that another lawyer, Mourtada Mansour, would represent the Mubaraks. Cairo criminal court was scheduled to start proceedings in this case on March 8, 2011,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbashayer.com/news-130937.html |title=Ø¬Ø±ÙØ¯Ø© Ø§ÙØ¨Ø´Ø§ÙØ± | Ø­ÙÙØ¯Ø© ÙØ¹ØªØ°Ø± Ø¹Ù ÙØ¶ÙØ© ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙÙØ±ØªØ¶Ù ÙÙØ¨Ù | |publisher=Elbashayer.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> however, on that day neither Mubarak nor his council appeared in court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/march/8/mobarak_money.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª ØªØ¤ÙØ¯ ÙØ±Ø§Ø± Ø§ÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø¨ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ù Ø¨Ø§ÙØªØ­ÙØ¸ Ø¹ÙÙ Ø£ÙÙØ§Ù ÙØ¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙØ£Ø³Ø±ØªÙ |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-08 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The court reaffirmed the travel ban on the Mubarak family and upheld the decision by the prosecutor to freeze the Mubaraks' accounts, citing that there is sufficient evidence to suspect Mubarak and his family of profiteering and misappropriation of public funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/465/2011/03/08/27/66267.aspx |title=Lawyers did not attend it ... Cairo Criminal Endorses the decision of the Attorney General to hold the funds Mubarak and his family |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The Mubaraks were contesting the travel ban in appeals court, while a criminal court was to convene to consider the financial charges.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hamad Al-Chalabi and Fatima Abu Shanab |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289932&IssueID=2069 |title="The police" supports the prevention of Mubarak and his family from their money and "Court of appeal" postpone the disclosure of confidential accounts for today's meeting |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
